When they grow at all, they grow exponentially. But they're tricky to grow. Which means the difference in outcome between someone who's adept at it and someone who's not is very great.

question: Why does the text recommend avoiding intermediaries between you and your audience?
answer: The text recommends avoiding intermediaries between you and your audience to achieve liberation and success in your work, as it can be more advantageous to establish direct connections with your audience.
chunk: To the extent you can, avoid letting intermediaries come between you and your audience. In some types of work this is inevitable, but it's so liberating to escape it that you might be better off switching to an adjacent type if that will let you go direct.

question: According to the text, what is compared to working in terms of facing challenges and the need for technique?
answer: Sailing
chunk: You don't just put out your sail and get blown forward by inspiration. There are headwinds and currents and hidden shoals. So there's a technique to working, just as there is to sailing.

question: How did Einstein find new ideas according to the text?
answer: Einstein found new ideas by seizing on signs of breakage and understanding the implications of Maxwell's equations due to his strictness, not by actively searching for new ideas.
chunk: To find new ideas you have to seize on signs of breakage instead of looking away. That's what Einstein did. He was able to see the wild implications of Maxwell's equations not so much because he was looking for new ideas as because he was stricter.

question: Why does Y Combinator encourage founders to focus on growth rate rather than absolute numbers?
answer: Y Combinator encourages founders to focus on growth rate rather than absolute numbers to prevent early discouragement, guide the company's evolution, and achieve exponential growth.
chunk: Y Combinator encourages founders to focus on growth rate rather than absolute numbers. It prevents them from being discouraged early on, when the absolute numbers are still low. It also helps them decide what to focus on: you can use growth rate as a compass to tell you how to evolve the company. But the main advantage is that by focusing on growth rate you tend to get something that grows exponentially.

question: How can work serve as a refuge from the difficulties of everyday life according to the text?
answer: Work can serve as a refuge from the difficulties of everyday life by choosing work that's pure, as its very difficulties can protect you from your problems, offering a productive form of escapism.
chunk: Indeed, work can to some extent protect you from your problems. If you choose work that's pure, its very difficulties will serve as a refuge from the difficulties of everyday life. If this is escapism, it's a very productive form of it, and one that has been used by some of the greatest minds in history.

question: What is the significance of finishing tasks according to the text?
answer: Finishing tasks is not just about tidiness or discipline but can lead to the best work in many projects.
chunk: Try to finish what you start, though, even if it turns out to be more work than you expected. Finishing things is not just an exercise in tidiness or self-discipline. In many projects a lot of the best work happens in what was meant to be the final stage.

question: Why did it take the greater part of a century for the heliocentric model to be generally accepted, even among astronomers?
answer: It took the greater part of a century for the heliocentric model to be generally accepted, even among astronomers, because new ideas can seem radical and rule-breaking initially, but eventually become widely accepted and reasonable as the perception evolves over time.
chunk: Few understand the degree of rule-breaking required, because new ideas seem much more conservative once they succeed. They seem perfectly reasonable once you're using the new model of the world they brought with them. But they didn't at the time; it took the greater part of a century for the heliocentric model to be generally accepted, even among astronomers, because it felt so wrong.

question: What is the recommended approach for young and ambitious individuals who are unsure of what to work on?
answer: The recommended approach is to take action, be curious, try lots of things, meet lots of people, read lots of books, and ask lots of questions to increase the chances of discovering the right path.
chunk: What should you do if you're young and ambitious but don't know what to work on? What you should not do is drift along passively, assuming the problem will solve itself. You need to take action. But there is no systematic procedure you can follow. When you read biographies of people who've done great work, it's remarkable how much luck is involved. They discover what to work on as a result of a chance meeting, or by reading a book they happen to pick up. So you need to make yourself a big target for luck, and the way to do that is to be curious. Try lots of things, meet lots of people, read lots of books, ask lots of questions.

question: What is the recommended approach for distributing attention among different topics, according to the text?
answer: Distribute attention according to something more like a power law, being professionally curious about a few topics and idly curious about many more.
chunk: Don't divide your attention evenly between many topics though, or you'll spread yourself too thin. You want to distribute it according to something more like a power law. Be professionally curious about a few topics and idly curious about many more.

question: Why is it almost inevitable that early work in many fields is based on other people's work?
answer: It is almost inevitable that early work in many fields is based on other people's work because projects usually arise as a reaction to previous work. When starting out, individuals don't have their own previous work to react to, so they have to base their early work on someone else's.
chunk: In many fields it's almost inevitable that your early work will be in some sense based on other people's. Projects rarely arise in a vacuum. They're usually a reaction to previous work. When you're first starting out, you don't have any previous work; if you're going to react to something, it has to be someone else's. Once you're established, you can react to your own. But while the former gets called derivative and the latter doesn't, structurally the two cases are more similar than they seem.

question: How can work compound by teaching you, according to the text?
answer: Work can compound by teaching you because learning compounds, leading to exponential growth even if you feel like you're failing in the short term.
chunk: There are two ways work can compound. It can compound directly, in the sense that doing well in one cycle causes you to do better in the next. That happens for example when you're building infrastructure, or growing an audience or brand. Or work can compound by teaching you, since learning compounds. This second case is an interesting one because you may feel you're doing badly as it's happening. You may be failing to achieve your immediate goal. But if you're learning a lot, then you're getting exponential growth nonetheless.

question: What can happen if you work too hard according to the text?
answer: If you work too hard, you may experience diminishing returns, fatigue, impaired cognitive function, and potential damage to your health.
chunk: For example, while you must work hard, it's possible to work too hard, and if you do that you'll find you get diminishing returns: fatigue will make you stupid, and eventually even damage your health. The point at which work yields diminishing returns depends on the type. Some of the hardest types you might only be able to do for four or five hours a day.

question: What does the text suggest regarding the influence of competitors on one's actions?
answer: The text suggests that individuals should not let competitors dictate their actions or choices and should instead focus on working harder.
chunk: Competition can be an effective motivator, but don't let it choose the problem for you; don't let yourself get drawn into chasing something just because others are. In fact, don't let competitors make you do anything much more specific than work harder.

question: How can overlooked ideas be discovered according to the text?
answer: Overlooked ideas can be discovered by starting from what's obscuring them, such as cherished but mistaken principles, which create a dead zone of valuable ideas that are unexplored because they contradict the mistaken principles.
chunk: You could also discover overlooked ideas by working in the other direction: by starting from what's obscuring them. Every cherished but mistaken principle is surrounded by a dead zone of valuable ideas that are unexplored because they contradict it.

question: What does the text suggest one must do if they lack the aptitude and interest required for managing projects on a larger scale?
answer: The text suggests that if one lacks the aptitude and interest required for managing projects on a larger scale, they must either force themselves to learn management as a second language or avoid such projects.
chunk: Most of us can benefit from collaborating with colleagues, but some projects require people on a larger scale, and starting one of those is not for everyone. If you want to run a project like that, you'll have to become a manager, and managing well takes aptitude and interest like any other kind of work. If you don't have them, there is no middle path: you must either force yourself to learn management as a second language, or avoid such projects.

question: What are the two forms of ambition mentioned in the text and how do they relate to doing great work?
answer: The two forms of ambition mentioned in the text are one that precedes interest in the subject and one that grows out of it. Most people who do great work have a mix of these forms of ambition. Having more of the ambition that precedes interest in the subject makes it harder to decide what to do.
chunk: The nature of ambition exacerbates this problem. Ambition comes in two forms, one that precedes interest in the subject and one that grows out of it. Most people who do great work have a mix, and the more you have of the former, the harder it will be to decide what to do.

question: How can ambitious individuals protect themselves from setbacks impacting their morale?
answer: Ambitious individuals can protect themselves from setbacks impacting their morale by considering setbacks as a natural part of the process and not allowing them to demoralize them like a burst balloon.
chunk: One of the biggest mistakes ambitious people make is to allow setbacks to destroy their morale all at once, like a balloon bursting. You can inoculate yourself against this by explicitly considering setbacks a part of your process. Solving hard problems always involves some backtracking.

question: According to the text, what should you do if you discover something more exciting while working on a particular task?
answer: If you discover something more exciting while working on one thing, don't be afraid to switch.
chunk: But fields aren't people; you don't owe them any loyalty. If in the course of working on one thing you discover another that's more exciting, don't be afraid to switch.

question: What kind of ideas are described as the right kind of crazy in the text?
answer: Ideas that are described as the right kind of crazy in the text are exciting, rich in implications, and not merely bad.
chunk: Indeed, if you think about it, a good new idea has to seem bad to most people, or someone would have already explored it. So what you're looking for is ideas that seem crazy, but the right kind of crazy. How do you recognize these? You can't with certainty. Often ideas that seem bad are bad. But ideas that are the right kind of crazy tend to be exciting; they're rich in implications; whereas ideas that are merely bad tend to be depressing.

question: According to the text, what indicator is the prestige of a type of work considered to be?
answer: The prestige of a type of work is considered to be at best a trailing indicator and sometimes completely mistaken.
chunk: The prestige of a type of work is at best a trailing indicator and sometimes completely mistaken. If you do anything well enough, you'll make it prestigious. So the question to ask about a type of work is not how much prestige it has, but how well it could be done.

question: According to the text, what is considered the best guide for determining what's worth paying attention to?
answer: Curiosity
chunk: Curiosity is the best guide. Your curiosity never lies, and it knows more than you do about what's worth paying attention to.

question: What is the recommended approach to ensure that what you're making is something people actually want according to the text?
answer: According to the text, the recommended approach is to make something you yourself want.
chunk: If you're making something for people, make sure it's something they actually want. The best way to do this is to make something you yourself want. Write the story you want to read; build the tool you want to use. Since your friends probably have similar interests, this will also get you your initial audience.

question: According to the text, what is another permissible lie that can lead to discovering something new?
answer: Exaggerating the importance of what you're working on.
chunk: Another permissible lie is to exaggerate the importance of what you're working on, at least in your own mind. If that helps you discover something new, it may turn out not to have been a lie after all.

question: Why is Silicon Valley tolerant of failure according to the text?
answer: Silicon Valley is tolerant of failure because people will only continue to support you if you learn from your failures.
chunk: This is one reason Silicon Valley is so tolerant of failure. People in Silicon Valley aren't blindly tolerant of failure. They'll only continue to bet on you if you're learning from your failures. But if you are, you are in fact a good bet: maybe your company didn't grow the way you wanted, but you yourself have, and that should yield results eventually.

question: According to the text, how does popular culture misinterpret the relationship between strictness and rule-breaking?
answer: Popular culture has a broken model as it assumes that in trivial matters, strictness and rule-breaking are opposed, whereas in important matters, rule-breakers can be truly strict.
chunk: Strictness plus rule-breaking sounds like a strange combination. In popular culture they're opposed. But popular culture has a broken model in this respect. It implicitly assumes that issues are trivial ones, and in trivial matters strictness and rule-breaking are opposed. But in questions that really matter, only rule-breakers can be truly strict.

question: How do novices, outsiders, and individuals with Asperger's syndrome contribute to making new discoveries according to the text?
answer: Novices, outsiders, and individuals with Asperger's syndrome contribute to making new discoveries by not adhering to established rules or assumptions in a field, which allows them to have independent-mindedness and develop new ideas.
chunk: The other way to break rules is not to care about them, or perhaps even to know they exist. This is why novices and outsiders often make new discoveries; their ignorance of a field's assumptions acts as a source of temporary passive independent-mindedness. Aspies also seem to have a kind of immunity to conventional beliefs. Several I know say that this helps them to have new ideas.

question: What are some of the forces that can lead you astray when trying to figure out what to work on, according to the text?
answer: Pretentiousness, fashion, fear, money, politics, other people's wishes, and eminent frauds can lead you astray when trying to figure out what to work on.
chunk: There are a lot of forces that will lead you astray when you're trying to figure out what to work on. Pretentiousness, fashion, fear, money, politics, other people's wishes, eminent frauds. But if you stick to what you find genuinely interesting, you'll be proof against all of them. If you're interested, you're not astray.

question: Why does the text suggest that the value of an audience doesn't grow linearly with its size?
answer: The text suggests that the value of an audience doesn't grow linearly with its size because a small but dedicated audience can be sufficient to sustain one's work. Even a handful of people who genuinely love what you're doing can be enough to support your work effectively.
chunk: An audience is a critical component of morale. If you're a scholar, your audience may be your peers; in the arts, it may be an audience in the traditional sense. Either way it doesn't need to be big. The value of an audience doesn't grow anything like linearly with its size. Which is bad news if you're famous, but good news if you're just starting out, because it means a small but dedicated audience can be enough to sustain you. If a handful of people genuinely love what you're doing, that's enough.

question: What is the relationship between crossing thresholds and exponential growth according to the text?
answer: The text states that crossing thresholds leads to exponential growth: the winning side in a battle usually suffers less damage, making them more likely to win in the future. Additionally, exponential growth helps in crossing thresholds in a market with network effects, allowing a company that grows fast enough to shut out potential competitors.
chunk: It's remarkable how often a situation with one source of superlinear returns also has the other. Crossing thresholds leads to exponential growth: the winning side in a battle usually suffers less damage, which makes them more likely to win in the future. And exponential growth helps you cross thresholds: in a market with network effects, a company that grows fast enough can shut out potential competitors.

question: What is the significance of the emperors of ideas being able to design bombs that defeat the emperors of territory?
answer: The significance lies in the shift of power dynamics where ideas have now become powerful enough to overcome traditional territorial power. This signifies a new era where intellectual strength can triumph over physical dominance.
chunk: That has changed in the last few centuries. Now the emperors of ideas can design bombs that defeat the emperors of territory. But this phenomenon is still so new that we haven't fully assimilated it. Few even of the participants realize they're benefitting from exponential growth or ask what they can learn from other instances of it.

question: According to the text, what is the nature of work in terms of starting and keeping working?
answer: The nature of work involves a higher energy threshold to start working compared to keeping working, requiring strategies to overcome the initial inertia.
chunk: It will probably be harder to start working than to keep working. You'll often have to trick yourself to get over that initial threshold. Don't worry about this; it's the nature of work, not a flaw in your character. Work has a sort of activation energy, both per day and per project. And since this threshold is fake in the sense that it's higher than the energy required to keep going, it's ok to tell yourself a lie of corresponding magnitude to get over it.

question: Why is fame considered an example of a phenomenon with superlinear returns?
answer: Fame is viewed as a phenomenon with superlinear returns because it grows exponentially as existing fans attract new ones, and it is concentrated due to the concept of thresholds limiting the number of individuals on the A-list.
chunk: Fame is an interesting example of a phenomenon that combines both sources of superlinear returns. Fame grows exponentially because existing fans bring you new ones. But the fundamental reason it's so concentrated is thresholds: there's only so much room on the A-list in the average person's head.

question: How does the author trick themselves into starting work in the morning?
answer: The author tricks themselves into starting work by saying they will just read over what they have so far, which often leads to finding mistakes or incomplete parts, motivating them to continue working.
chunk: It's usually a mistake to lie to yourself if you want to do great work, but this is one of the rare cases where it isn't. When I'm reluctant to start work in the morning, I often trick myself by saying "I'll just read over what I've got so far." Five minutes later I've found something that seems mistaken or incomplete, and I'm off.

question: According to the text, what are the two forms of procrastination related to starting work, and which one is considered more dangerous?
answer: The two forms of procrastination related to starting work are per-day and per-project procrastination. Per-project procrastination is considered more dangerous.
chunk: Since there are two senses of starting work — per day and per project — there are also two forms of procrastination. Per-project procrastination is far the more dangerous. You put off starting that ambitious project from year to year because the time isn't quite right. When you're procrastinating in units of years, you can get a lot not done.

question: Why is it important to take care of your body according to the text?
answer: It is important to take care of your body because ultimately morale is physical, and thinking is closely linked to bodily health. Regular exercise, proper nutrition, adequate sleep, and avoiding harmful substances are essential for maintaining optimal thinking abilities. Running and walking are particularly beneficial for enhancing cognitive functions.
chunk: Ultimately morale is physical. You think with your body, so it's important to take care of it. That means exercising regularly, eating and sleeping well, and avoiding the more dangerous kinds of drugs. Running and walking are particularly good forms of exercise because they're good for thinking.

question: How does the text describe the behavior of aggressively independent-minded individuals towards rules and project activation energy?
answer: The text describes aggressively independent-minded individuals as being energized and not deterred by rules; instead, breaking rules gives them additional energy. They are also driven by the sheer audacity of a project, which provides the activation energy needed to start it.
chunk: The aggressively independent-minded are the naughty ones. Rules don't merely fail to stop them; breaking rules gives them additional energy. For this sort of person, delight at the sheer audacity of a project sometimes supplies enough activation energy to get it started.

question: Why does the text suggest giving different types of work a chance to show what they're like?
answer: The text suggests giving different types of work a chance to show what they're like because it helps you understand the characteristics of each type of work and allows you to explore and experience different perspectives within a field.
chunk: When in doubt, optimize for interestingness. Fields change as you learn more about them. What mathematicians do, for example, is very different from what you do in high school math classes. So you need to give different types of work a chance to show you what they're like. But a field should become increasingly interesting as you learn more about it. If it doesn't, it's probably not for you.

question: According to the text, if an oracle provided a single word answer to the secret of doing great work, what word would it most likely be?
answer: Curiosity
chunk: Notice how often that word has come up. If you asked an oracle the secret to doing great work and the oracle replied with a single word, my bet would be on "curiosity."

question: What insight does the text provide about people's approach to problem-solving versus problem selection?
answer: The text suggests that people exhibit more originality in solving problems than in deciding which problems to work on. It indicates that individuals, even the smartest ones, can be conservative when choosing problems to tackle and may gravitate towards fashionable problems.
chunk: People show much more originality in solving problems than in deciding which problems to solve. Even the smartest can be surprisingly conservative when deciding what to work on. People who'd never dream of being fashionable in any other way get sucked into working on fashionable problems.

question: What are the benefits of working on an unfashionable problem according to the text?
answer: The benefits include the absence of hype or hurry, occupied opportunists and critics, old-school solidity, and a satisfying sense of economy in cultivating ideas that would otherwise be wasted.
chunk: Working on an unfashionable problem can be very pleasing. There's no hype or hurry. Opportunists and critics are both occupied elsewhere. The existing work often has an old-school solidity. And there's a satisfying sense of economy in cultivating ideas that would otherwise be wasted.

question: How can the people you spend time with affect your morale according to the text?
answer: The people you spend time with can either increase or decrease your energy levels, impacting your morale. It is advised to seek out individuals who enhance your energy and avoid those who diminish it. Taking care of certain individuals may take precedence despite their effect on your morale.
chunk: The people you spend time with will also have a big effect on your morale. You'll find there are some who increase your energy and others who decrease it, and the effect someone has is not always what you'd expect. Seek out the people who increase your energy and avoid those who decrease it. Though of course if there's someone you need to take care of, that takes precedence.

question: What does the text imply about starting new projects and deceiving oneself about the amount of work involved?
answer: The text implies that it can be beneficial to deceive oneself about the amount of work a project will entail when starting a new project, using the example of saying 'How hard could it be?' to begin great things. Underestimating the work can lead to starting and achieving great outcomes, and this deceptive self-assurance can serve as a motivator to initiate projects.
chunk: Similar techniques work for starting new projects. It's ok to lie to yourself about how much work a project will entail, for example. Lots of great things began with someone saying "How hard could it be?"

question: What is the effect of compounding work according to the text?
answer: The effect of compounding work is exponential growth.
chunk: If you do work that compounds, you'll get exponential growth. Most people who do this do it unconsciously, but it's worth stopping to think about. Learning, for example, is an instance of this phenomenon: the more you learn about something, the easier it is to learn more. Growing an audience is another: the more fans you have, the more new fans they'll bring you.

question: What is the key to achieving great things according to the text?
answer: Consistency is the key to achieving great things, as highlighted in the text.
chunk: The reason we're surprised is that we underestimate the cumulative effect of work. Writing a page a day doesn't sound like much, but if you do it every day you'll write a book a year. That's the key: consistency. People who do great things don't get a lot done every day. They get something done, rather than nothing.

question: According to the text, can curiosity be commanded to drive great work?
answer: No, curiosity cannot be commanded to drive great work.
chunk: That doesn't translate directly to advice. It's not enough just to be curious, and you can't command curiosity anyway. But you can nurture it and let it drive you.

question: What advice does the text give regarding learning and overoptimization?
answer: The text advises against overoptimizing what you're learning and warns against limiting yourself to only learning things known to be valuable, as you may not yet know what will be valuable in the future.
chunk: But don't overoptimize what you're learning. Don't limit yourself to learning things that are already known to be valuable. You're learning; you don't know for sure yet what's going to be valuable, and if you're too strict you'll lop off the outliers.

question: What outcomes do companies with high growth rates tend to achieve, according to the text?
answer: Companies with high growth rates tend to become immensely valuable.
chunk: Startups can also grow exponentially, and we see the same pattern there. Some manage to achieve high growth rates. Most don't. And as a result you get qualitatively different outcomes: the companies with high growth rates tend to become immensely valuable, while the ones with lower growth rates may not even survive.

question: Why is it often challenging to see something obvious or have new ideas according to the text?
answer: It is challenging to see something obvious or have new ideas because it requires a change in perspective, specifically the need to change the way we look at the world. Our perception is influenced by models that both assist us and constrain us, making it difficult to break free from existing paradigms. Discovering new ideas becomes easier when we are able to recognize and fix flawed models, a task that is inherently difficult.
chunk: Seeing something obvious sounds easy. And yet empirically having new ideas is hard. What's the source of this apparent contradiction? It's that seeing the new idea usually requires you to change the way you look at the world. We see the world through models that both help and constrain us. When you fix a broken model, new ideas become obvious. But noticing and fixing a broken model is hard. That's how new ideas can be both obvious and yet hard to discover: they're easy to see after you do something hard.

question: What are some principles that people in a specific field may be overly attached to, according to the text? What are the potential outcomes of discarding these principles?
answer: People in the field may be overly attached to principles that are not as self-evident as they think. Discarding these principles can open up new possibilities and perspectives for growth and innovation in their work.
chunk: What are people in your field religious about, in the sense of being too attached to some principle that might not be as self-evident as they think? What becomes possible if you discard it?

question: Why are people more conservative when choosing problems than solutions according to the text?
answer: People are more conservative when choosing problems than solutions because problems are seen as bigger bets that can occupy a significant amount of time, whereas exploring solutions might only take days. However, the text suggests that people may be too conservative not just due to risk, but also due to fashion, with unfashionable problems being undervalued.
chunk: One reason people are more conservative when choosing problems than solutions is that problems are bigger bets. A problem could occupy you for years, while exploring a solution might only take days. But even so I think most people are too conservative. They're not merely responding to risk, but to fashion as well. Unfashionable problems are undervalued.

question: What advice does the text give about working on important problems and taking a break to explore interesting pursuits?
answer: The text advises people to consider overlooked problems in their neighborhood and take breaks from serious work to explore interesting pursuits, as the answer to what would be really interesting may be more important than it seems.
chunk: You do need to work on important problems, but almost everyone is too conservative about what counts as one. And if there's an important but overlooked problem in your neighborhood, it's probably already on your subconscious radar screen. So try asking yourself: if you were going to take a break from "serious" work to work on something just because it would be really interesting, what would you do? The answer is probably more important than it seems.

question: According to the text, how does great work happen?
answer: Great work happens by focusing consistently on something you're genuinely interested in.
chunk: There may be some jobs where you have to work diligently for years at things you hate before you get to the good part, but this is not how great work happens. Great work happens by focusing consistently on something you're genuinely interested in. When you pause to take stock, you're surprised how far you've come.

question: Why is it important to understand the concept of superlinear returns according to the text?
answer: It's important to understand the concept of superlinear returns because you can't understand the world without it, and ambitious individuals should pay attention to it as it will be the wave they surf on.
chunk: You can't understand the world without understanding the concept of superlinear returns. And if you're ambitious you definitely should, because this will be the wave you surf on.

question: What is the prospect of superlinear returns for performance according to the text?
answer: The prospect of superlinear returns for performance is expanding in both directions, with more types of work offering superlinear returns and the returns themselves growing.
chunk: The prospect of superlinear returns for performance is an exciting one for the ambitious. And there's good news in this department: this territory is expanding in both directions. There are more types of work in which you can get superlinear returns, and the returns themselves are growing.

question: Why is exponential growth often underrated in its early stages?
answer: Exponential growth is often underrated in its early stages because the curve feels flat in the beginning, even though it is still following an exponential trajectory.
chunk: The trouble with exponential growth is that the curve feels flat in the beginning. It isn't; it's still a wonderful exponential curve. But we can't grasp that intuitively, so we underrate exponential growth in its early stages.

question: According to the text, how can work feel less burdensome for individuals?
answer: Work can feel less burdensome for individuals if they are working on something they find very interesting and fulfilling, aligning with their passion and interests.
chunk: Yes, you'll have to work hard. But again, lots of people have to work hard. And if you're working on something you find very interesting, which you necessarily will if you're on the right path, the work will probably feel less burdensome than a lot of your peers'.

question: What does great work usually entail according to the text?
answer: Great work usually entails spending what would seem to most people an unreasonable amount of time on a problem. You can't think of this time as a cost, or it will seem too high. You have to find the work sufficiently engaging as it's happening.
chunk: Great work usually entails spending what would seem to most people an unreasonable amount of time on a problem. You can't think of this time as a cost, or it will seem too high. You have to find the work sufficiently engaging as it's happening.

question: According to the text, what is a key aspect of originality?
answer: A key aspect of originality is being comfortable with confusion and being motivated to solve puzzles.
chunk: Think about what's happening at the moment just before a new idea is discovered. Often someone with sufficient expertise is puzzled about something. Which means that originality consists partly of puzzlement — of confusion! You have to be comfortable enough with the world being full of puzzles that you're willing to see them, but not so comfortable that you don't want to solve them.

question: According to the text, who are the discoveries waiting to be made by?
answer: The discoveries are waiting to be made by anyone, including the reader.
chunk: The discoveries are out there, waiting to be made. Why not by you?

question: What holds many people back from trying to do great work according to the text?
answer: A combination of modesty and fear
chunk: Many more people could try to do great work than do. What holds them back is a combination of modesty and fear. It seems presumptuous to try to be Newton or Shakespeare. It also seems hard; surely if you tried something like that, you'd fail. Presumably the calculation is rarely explicit. Few people consciously decide not to try to do great work. But that's what's going on subconsciously; they shy away from the question.

question: How can you identify common overlooked problems according to the text?
answer: According to the text, you can identify common overlooked problems by being self-indulgent, letting your curiosity guide you, and temporarily tuning out the voice that insists on focusing only on 'important' problems.
chunk: But the most common type of overlooked problem is not explicitly unfashionable in the sense of being out of fashion. It just doesn't seem to matter as much as it actually does. How do you find these? By being self-indulgent — by letting your curiosity have its way, and tuning out, at least temporarily, the little voice in your head that says you should only be working on "important" problems.

question: Why does the text suggest consciously cultivating your taste in the work done in your field?
answer: The text suggests consciously cultivating your taste in the work done in your field to understand which is the best and what makes it so, thus providing a clear goal to aim for in one's work.
chunk: Consciously cultivate your taste in the work done in your field. Until you know which is the best and what makes it so, you don't know what you're aiming for.

question: According to the text, what distinguishes people who discover whole new fields when it comes to originality in problem-solving?
answer: Originality in choosing problems
chunk: Originality in choosing problems seems to matter even more than originality in solving them. That's what distinguishes the people who discover whole new fields. So what might seem to be merely the initial step — deciding what to work on — is in a sense the key to the whole game.

question: What is the significance of really good questions, according to the text?
answer: According to the text, a really good question is considered a partial discovery, leading to excitingly novel territory and deeper understanding.
chunk: Part of the reason we underrate questions is the way they're used in schools. In schools they tend to exist only briefly before being answered, like unstable particles. But a really good question can be much more than that. A really good question is a partial discovery. How do new species arise? Is the force that makes objects fall to earth the same as the one that keeps planets in their orbits? By even asking such questions you were already in excitingly novel territory.

question: Why is per-project procrastination considered dangerous according to the text?
answer: Per-project procrastination is dangerous because it masquerades as productive work, making individuals believe they are actively working on tasks when, in reality, they are avoiding important projects. This deception prevents individuals from recognizing and addressing their procrastination effectively.
chunk: One reason per-project procrastination is so dangerous is that it usually camouflages itself as work. You're not just sitting around doing nothing; you're working industriously on something else. So per-project procrastination doesn't set off the alarms that per-day procrastination does. You're too busy to notice it.

question: What insight does the text provide about exploring unfashionable problems in a field?
answer: The text suggests that unfashionable problems, believed to be fully explored, often have hidden potential that can be revealed by individuals who are able to see beyond existing limitations. It highlights the importance of not being deterred by skepticism and the common misconception that certain fields are tapped out, as there may still be unexplored opportunities for innovation and advancement.
chunk: One of the most interesting kinds of unfashionable problem is the problem that people think has been fully explored, but hasn't. Great work often takes something that already exists and shows its latent potential. Durer and Watt both did this. So if you're interested in a field that others think is tapped out, don't let their skepticism deter you. People are often wrong about this.

question: What is required to benefit from daydreaming according to the text?
answer: Working hard in the normal way and combining daydreaming with deliberate work that feeds it questions.
chunk: You have to be working hard in the normal way to benefit from this phenomenon, though. You can't just walk around daydreaming. The daydreaming has to be interleaved with deliberate work that feeds it questions.

question: How does actual expertise differ from the popular perception according to the text?
answer: Actual expertise differs from the popular perception in that experts are not always certain; being puzzled can be beneficial as long as the things one is puzzled about matter and no one else understands them.
chunk: This is one of the places where actual expertise differs most from the popular picture of it. In the popular picture, experts are certain. But actually the more puzzled you are, the better, so long as (a) the things you're puzzled about matter, and (b) no one else understands them either.

question: According to the text, how do you get from starting small to doing something great?
answer: By making successive versions.
chunk: How do you get from starting small to doing something great? By making successive versions. Great things are almost always made in successive versions. You start with something small and evolve it, and the final version is both cleverer and more ambitious than anything you could have planned.

question: Why does the text recommend periodically questioning whether you are working on what you most want to work on?
answer: The text suggests this practice to ensure that individuals are aligning their work with their true priorities and goals, highlighting the increasing risk of working on less important tasks as one gets older.
chunk: The way to beat it is to stop occasionally and ask yourself: Am I working on what I most want to work on? When you're young it's ok if the answer is sometimes no, but this gets increasingly dangerous as you get older.

question: According to the text, what is essential to do something exceptionally well?
answer: Being interested in it. Mere diligence is not enough.
chunk: There are many variables that affect how good your work is, and if you want to be an outlier you need to get nearly all of them right. For example, to do something exceptionally well, you have to be interested in it. Mere diligence is not enough. So in a world with superlinear returns, it's even more valuable to know what you're interested in, and to find ways to work on it. It will also be important to choose work that suits your circumstances. For example, if there's a kind of work that inherently requires a huge expenditure of time and energy, it will be increasingly valuable to do it when you're young and don't yet have children.

question: Why is being prolific considered underrated according to the text?
answer: Being prolific is underrated because trying different things increases the chance of discovering something new, even though it also means trying many things that may not work.
chunk: Being prolific is underrated. The more different things you try, the greater the chance of discovering something new. Understand, though, that trying lots of things will mean trying lots of things that don't work. You can't have a lot of good ideas without also having a lot of bad ones.

question: What are the factors in doing great work according to the text?
answer: The factors in doing great work according to the text are ability, interest, effort, and luck (which can be ignored due to lack of control). Effort is assumed if one wants to do great work, so the pivotal factors become ability and interest.
chunk: The factors in doing great work are factors in the literal, mathematical sense, and they are: ability, interest, effort, and luck. Luck by definition you can't do anything about, so we can ignore that. And we can assume effort, if you do in fact want to do great work. So the problem boils down to ability and interest. Can you find a kind of work where your ability and interest will combine to yield an explosion of new ideas?

question: What does the text recommend regarding starting new projects?
answer: The text recommends starting small and trying new things rather than studying everything that has been done before, as it leads to faster learning, more enjoyment, and better understanding of previous work.
chunk: Though it sounds more responsible to begin by studying everything that's been done before, you'll learn faster and have more fun by trying stuff. And you'll understand previous work better when you do look at it. So err on the side of starting. Which is easier when starting means starting small; those two ideas fit together like two puzzle pieces.

question: What is the role of curiosity in the four steps of doing great work according to the text?
answer: Curiosity is the key to all four steps in doing great work: choosing the field, reaching the frontier, noticing gaps, and driving exploration.
chunk: Curiosity is the key to all four steps in doing great work: it will choose the field for you, get you to the frontier, cause you to notice the gaps in it, and drive you to explore them. The whole process is a kind of dance with curiosity.

question: According to the text, what is the potential outcome of carrying multiple unanswered questions?
answer: Noticing a solution or realizing that two unanswered questions are the same.
chunk: Unanswered questions can be uncomfortable things to carry around with you. But the more you're carrying, the greater the chance of noticing a solution — or perhaps even more excitingly, noticing that two unanswered questions are the same.

question: According to the text, what will be the result of the switch away from institutions in terms of opportunity and inclusivity?
answer: The resulting democratization of opportunity will be greater and more authentic, allowing new winners who were previously excluded to emerge.
chunk: The switch away from institutions won't simply be an exodus of their current inhabitants. Many of the new winners will be people they'd never have let in. So the resulting democratization of opportunity will be both greater and more authentic than any tame intramural version the institutions themselves might have cooked up.

question: According to the text, is it easier to try to be the best or to try merely to be good?
answer: According to the text, it is easier to try to be the best than to try merely to be good.
chunk: Fortunately there's a kind of economy of scale here. Though it might seem like you'd be taking on a heavy burden by trying to be the best, in practice you often end up net ahead. It's exciting, and also strangely liberating. It simplifies things. In some ways it's easier to try to be the best than to try merely to be good.

question: What type of thinking can be powerful for problem-solving according to the text?
answer: Undirected thinking, such as when walking, taking a shower, or lying in bed, can be powerful for problem-solving.
chunk: Work doesn't just happen when you're trying to. There's a kind of undirected thinking you do when walking or taking a shower or lying in bed that can be very powerful. By letting your mind wander a little, you'll often solve problems you were unable to solve by frontal attack.

question: What is the significance of being promiscuously curious according to the text?
answer: The significance of being promiscuously curious according to the text is that it allows one to pull on various threads, start lots of small things, and potentially grow them into bigger endeavors.
chunk: It's better to be promiscuously curious — to pull a little bit on a lot of threads, and see what happens. Big things start small. The initial versions of big things were often just experiments, or side projects, or talks, which then grew into something bigger. So start lots of small things.

question: According to the text, what does the length of the essay serve as?
answer: A filter to identify individuals interested in doing great work.
chunk: Believe it or not, I tried to make this essay as short as I could. But its length at least means it acts as a filter. If you made it this far, you must be interested in doing great work. And if so you're already further along than you might realize, because the set of people willing to want to is small.

question: How does the text describe the relationship between knowledge growth and thresholds in learning?
answer: The text describes knowledge growth as exponential with thresholds in learning. Learning to ride a bicycle and mastering reading are examples of thresholds that enable faster learning. Discovering new fields through pushing boundaries is highlighted as a way to access new knowledge and discoveries.
chunk: The most important case combining both sources of superlinear returns may be learning. Knowledge grows exponentially, but there are also thresholds in it. Learning to ride a bicycle, for example. Some of these thresholds are akin to machine tools: once you learn to read, you're able to learn anything else much faster. But the most important thresholds of all are those representing new discoveries. Knowledge seems to be fractal in the sense that if you push hard at the boundary of one area of knowledge, you sometimes discover a whole new field. And if you do, you get first crack at all the new discoveries to be made in it. Newton did this, and so did Durer and Darwin.

question: According to the text, what happens when you let your mind wander?
answer: When you let your mind wander, it wanders to whatever you care about most at that moment.
chunk: Everyone knows to avoid distractions at work, but it's also important to avoid them in the other half of the cycle. When you let your mind wander, it wanders to whatever you care about most at that moment. So avoid the kind of distraction that pushes your work out of the top spot, or you'll waste this valuable type of thinking on the distraction instead. (Exception: Don't avoid love.)

question: Why do people often push through the initial phase of learning something new according to the text?
answer: People push through the initial phase of learning something new because they know from experience that learning new things always takes an initial push, and they understand the potential for exponential growth later on.
chunk: Something that grows exponentially can become so valuable that it's worth making an extraordinary effort to get it started. But since we underrate exponential growth early on, this too is mostly done unconsciously: people push through the initial, unrewarding phase of learning something new because they know from experience that learning new things always takes an initial push, or they grow their audience one fan at a time because they have nothing better to do. If people consciously realized they could invest in exponential growth, many more would do it.

question: According to the text, what challenge is presented to the reader regarding doing great work?
answer: The challenge presented to the reader is to decide consciously if they want to do great work.
chunk: So I'm going to pull a sneaky trick on you. Do you want to do great work, or not? Now you have to decide consciously. Sorry about that. I wouldn't have done it to a general audience. But we already know you're interested.

question: How does the text suggest individuals can take advantage of superlinear returns for performance?
answer: The text suggests that individuals can take advantage of superlinear returns by doing exceptionally good work at the far end of the curve where incremental effort becomes a bargain due to reduced competition and the intimidating nature of exceptional work.
chunk: The most obvious way to take advantage of superlinear returns for performance is by doing exceptionally good work. At the far end of the curve, incremental effort is a bargain. All the more so because there's less competition at the far end — and not just for the obvious reason that it's hard to do something exceptionally well, but also because people find the prospect so intimidating that few even try. Which means it's not just a bargain to do exceptional work, but a bargain even to try to.

question: What is emphasized in the text regarding the value of unanswered questions and acquiring new questions?
answer: The text emphasizes the value of being rich in unanswered questions and suggests that trying to answer existing questions is the best way to acquire new ones, leading to a cycle of questions.
chunk: It's a great thing to be rich in unanswered questions. And this is one of those situations where the rich get richer, because the best way to acquire new questions is to try answering existing ones. Questions don't just lead to answers, but also to more questions.

question: Why does the text suggest that if you don't try to be the best, you won't even be good?
answer: The text suggests this because ambition is a phenomenon where most errors are in one direction, and aiming to be the best is qualitatively different from just aiming to be good.
chunk: And that is what you're aiming for, because if you don't try to be the best, you won't even be good. This observation has been made by so many people in so many different fields that it might be worth thinking about why it's true. It could be because ambition is a phenomenon where almost all the error is in one direction — where almost all the shells that miss the target miss by falling short. Or it could be because ambition to be the best is a qualitatively different thing from ambition to be good. Or maybe being good is simply too vague a standard. Probably all three are true.

question: How does the text recommend determining if a game is worth playing when taking advantage of thresholds?
answer: The text recommends including a test to ensure the game is worth playing by assessing if something is mediocre yet still popular, as this could indicate a potential opportunity for improvement.
chunk: A principle for taking advantage of thresholds has to include a test to ensure the game is worth playing. Here's one that does: if you come across something that's mediocre yet still popular, it could be a good idea to replace it. For example, if a company makes a product that people dislike yet still buy, then presumably they'd buy a better alternative if you made one.

question: What is one of the biggest misconceptions about new ideas according to the text?
answer: One of the biggest misconceptions about new ideas is about the ratio of question to answer in their composition.
chunk: Few grasp this. One of the biggest misconceptions about new ideas is about the ratio of question to answer in their composition. People think big ideas are answers, but often the real insight was in the question.

question: What does the text suggest about the fear of failure and taking risks?
answer: The text suggests that one should not worry about being presumptuous, should not fear failure, and should be open to taking risks without being deterred by the possibility of failure. It indicates that having challenges or failures is a normal part of life and should not prevent someone from trying new things.
chunk: Don't worry about being presumptuous. You don't have to tell anyone. And if it's too hard and you fail, so what? Lots of people have worse problems than that. In fact you'll be lucky if it's the worst problem you have.

question: What concept is discussed in the text with respect to a fundamental change in returns for performance?
answer: Superlinear Returns
chunk: There's still plenty of the old world left, but the rate of change has been dramatic by historical standards. Especially considering what's at stake. It's hard to imagine a more fundamental change than one in the returns for performance.

question: According to the text, what is the key to finding the type of work one is most suited for?
answer: The key is trying different types of work to determine the best fit for one's ability and interest.
chunk: Here there are grounds for optimism. There are so many different ways to do great work, and even more that are still undiscovered. Out of all those different types of work, the one you're most suited for is probably a pretty close match. Probably a comically close match. It's just a question of finding it, and how far into it your ability and interest can take you. And you can only answer that by trying.

question: What does the text suggest about the nature of questions and the process of exploring them?
answer: The text suggests that the best questions may not appear significant at first but can lead to deeper insights when pursued, highlighting the unpredictability of the impact of exploring a question.
chunk: The best questions grow in the answering. You notice a thread protruding from the current paradigm and try pulling on it, and it just gets longer and longer. So don't require a question to be obviously big before you try answering it. You can rarely predict that. It's hard enough even to notice the thread, let alone to predict how much will unravel if you pull on it.

question: What are the two reasons mentioned in the text for a phenomenon, and how are they described in relation to each other?
answer: The two reasons mentioned in the text are progress in technology and the decreasing importance of organizations. They are described as so closely intertwined that they're more like one and a half reasons, emphasizing their interdependent nature and the way they contribute to the phenomenon.
chunk: There are two reasons for this, though they're so closely intertwined that they're more like one and a half: progress in technology, and the decreasing importance of organizations.

question: Why is it useful to make successive versions when creating something for people?
answer: Making successive versions is useful to get an initial version in front of people quickly and evolve it based on their response, improving the final product.
chunk: It's particularly useful to make successive versions when you're making something for people — to get an initial version in front of them quickly, and then evolve it based on their response.

question: How can ambitious individuals take advantage of the unlocking of ambition despite the opposition it faces from vested interests and ideologies?
answer: Ambitious individuals can take advantage of the unlocking of ambition by seizing the opportunities it brings, leveraging their drive and determination to navigate through challenges, and staying focused on their goals despite opposition from vested interests and conflicting ideologies.
chunk: Not everyone is happy about this great unlocking of ambition. It threatens some vested interests and contradicts some ideologies. But if you're an ambitious individual it's good news for you. How should you take advantage of it?

question: What key elements or strategies does the author suggest for achieving great work, according to the text?
answer: The author suggests that achieving great work involves a surprising amount of technique, indicating that success is not solely based on effort but on the strategic application of methods and skills. Additionally, the author hints at providing a condensed recipe or guide in one paragraph, implying a concise and effective approach to excellence in work.
chunk: There's a surprising amount of technique to doing great work. It's not just a matter of trying hard. I'm going to take a shot giving a recipe in one paragraph.

question: What was the significance of being part of an organization in ambitious projects 50 years ago according to the text?
answer: Being part of an organization was crucial for accessing resources, colleagues, and distribution in ambitious projects 50 years ago. Prestige was tied to the organization one belonged to, and exceptions like artists and writers also needed organizations to reach audiences.
chunk: Fifty years ago it used to be much more necessary to be part of an organization to work on ambitious projects. It was the only way to get the resources you needed, the only way to have colleagues, and the only way to get distribution. So in 1970 your prestige was in most cases the prestige of the organization you belonged to. And prestige was an accurate predictor, because if you weren't part of an organization, you weren't likely to achieve much. There were a handful of exceptions, most notably artists and writers, who worked alone using inexpensive tools and had their own brands. But even they were at the mercy of organizations for reaching audiences.

question: What heuristic is suggested in the text for determining research questions that may lead to new discoveries?
answer: One heuristic suggested in the text is to be driven by curiosity rather than careerism in research, giving free rein to curiosity instead of working on what you're supposed to.
chunk: It would be great if there were a way to find promising intellectual thresholds. Is there a way to tell which questions have whole new fields beyond them? I doubt we could ever predict this with certainty, but the prize is so valuable that it would be useful to have predictors that were even a little better than random, and there's hope of finding those. We can to some degree predict when a research problem isn't likely to lead to new discoveries: when it seems legit but boring. Whereas the kind that do lead to new discoveries tend to seem very mystifying, but perhaps unimportant. (If they were mystifying and obviously important, they'd be famous open questions with lots of people already working on them.) So one heuristic here is to be driven by curiosity rather than careerism — to give free rein to your curiosity instead of working on what you're supposed to.

question: What is the argument made in the text about superlinear returns for performance in business and other domains?
answer: The text argues that superlinear returns for performance are a feature of the world, not a result of rules we've created. It states that this phenomenon is observed in various areas like fame, power, military victories, knowledge, and benefit to humanity, where the rich tend to become richer.
chunk: It's obviously true that the returns for performance are superlinear in business. Some think this is a flaw of capitalism, and that if we changed the rules it would stop being true. But superlinear returns for performance are a feature of the world, not an artifact of rules we've invented. We see the same pattern in fame, power, military victories, knowledge, and even benefit to humanity. In all of these, the rich get richer.

question: Who should aim for superlinear returns according to the text?
answer: Ambitious people of two types: those who are confident in their abilities to thrive in a high-variation world and young individuals who can afford to take the risk.
chunk: Without the damping effect of institutions, there will be more variation in outcomes. Which doesn't imply everyone will be better off: people who do well will do even better, but those who do badly will do worse. That's an important point to bear in mind. Exposing oneself to superlinear returns is not for everyone. Most people will be better off as part of the pool. So who should shoot for superlinear returns? Ambitious people of two types: those who know they're so good that they'll be net ahead in a world with higher variation, and those, particularly the young, who can afford to risk trying it to find out.

question: According to the text, what is the importance of returning to questions that have been carried for a long time?
answer: Returning to questions that have been carried for a long time, including those from childhood, can inspire great work and is just as important as keeping youthful dreams alive.
chunk: Sometimes you carry a question for a long time. Great work often comes from returning to a question you first noticed years before — in your childhood, even — and couldn't stop thinking about. People talk a lot about the importance of keeping your youthful dreams alive, but it's just as important to keep your youthful questions alive.

question: How does the text illustrate the limitations of 'seek competition' as a heuristic?
answer: The text demonstrates the ineffectiveness of 'seek competition' as a heuristic by pointing out that competing for a prize that is not worth it renders the heuristic useless.
chunk: What about step functions? Are there also useful heuristics of the form "seek thresholds" or "seek competition?" Here the situation is trickier. The existence of a threshold doesn't guarantee the game will be worth playing. If you play a round of Russian roulette, you'll be in a situation with a threshold, certainly, but in the best case you're no better off. "Seek competition" is similarly useless; what if the prize isn't worth competing for? Sufficiently fast exponential growth guarantees both the shape and magnitude of the return curve — because something that grows fast enough will grow big even if it's trivially small at first — but thresholds only guarantee the shape.

question: What does the text emphasize about taking risks in one's career?
answer: The text emphasizes that individuals should take as much risk as they can afford, as avoiding occasional failure may indicate being too conservative.
chunk: Choose work you have a natural aptitude for and a deep interest in. Develop a habit of working on your own projects; it doesn't matter what they are so long as you find them excitingly ambitious. Work as hard as you can without burning out, and this will eventually bring you to one of the frontiers of knowledge. These look smooth from a distance, but up close they're full of gaps. Notice and explore such gaps, and if you're lucky one will expand into a whole new field. Take as much risk as you can afford; if you're not failing occasionally you're probably being too conservative. Seek out the best colleagues. Develop good taste and learn from the best examples. Be honest, especially with yourself. Exercise and eat and sleep well and avoid the more dangerous drugs. When in doubt, follow your curiosity. It never lies, and it knows more than you do about what's worth paying attention to.

question: What opportunities are available to more people in the current world according to the text?
answer: More people can have the freedom that artists and writers had in the 20th century, with ambitious projects that don't require much initial funding and new ways to learn, make money, find colleagues, and reach audiences.
chunk: A world dominated by organizations damped variation in the returns for performance. But this world has eroded significantly just in my lifetime. Now a lot more people can have the freedom that artists and writers had in the 20th century. There are lots of ambitious projects that don't require much initial funding, and lots of new ways to learn, make money, find colleagues, and reach audiences.

question: What does the author suggest is the right strategy for most people who want to do great work?
answer: The author suggests that the right strategy for most people who want to do great work is not to plan too much. Instead, they should do whatever seems most interesting at each stage and gives them the best options for the future, a method called 'staying upwind.'
chunk: I think for most people who want to do great work, the right strategy is not to plan too much. At each stage do whatever seems most interesting and gives you the best options for the future. I call this approach "staying upwind." This is how most people who've done great work seem to have done it.

question: According to the text, what is the analogy used to describe doing great work?
answer: Doing great work is compared to a depth-first search with the root node being the desire to succeed.
chunk: Doing great work is a depth-first search whose root node is the desire to. So "If at first you don't succeed, try, try again" isn't quite right. It should be: If at first you don't succeed, either try again, or backtrack and then try again.
